Negroes on white campus Apprehension limits racial interaction
By HOLLACE GOLDBERG Third in a series
What is it like to be a Negro
student on a white campus? Each
Negro student has his own per-
sonal opinion.
"There’s no difference,“ main
tained one sophomore, “Negro is
just a legal term the white man
made up for convenience."
“No, our culture is different,"
projected a dark-skinned boy.
"It’s composed of James Brown
and the Supremes."
"They stare at me in class when
we discuss slavery or Africa,"
noted one young girl. “I guess
it’s out of curiosity."
"People yell out of car windows
at me," put in an adamant coed,
cursing the University under her
breath. This was Doris, a dis-
satisfied Negro, bitter towards
her four years at the University.
Doris sells Black power but-
tons, “a quarter for Negroes, a
dollar for whites."
"You can’t write an article on
Negroes," she told this reporter.
"Anything you write, white people
will think is interesting... but to
colored people it won’t mean a thing."
Only colored people know and
understand colored people, she
maintains. This seems to be
true, for the white student cannot
find a typical Negro student from
which to generalize about the
200-400 colored undergraduates
on campus.
The Negroes compose a hete-
rogeneous population, demarcat-
ed from the rest of the student
body by skin color and/or a few
tables in the Main Dining Hall
or the Student Union. The Negro
students’ views are varied, their
experiences largely dissimilar,
and even their skin tones are of
different shades.
This is an article about the
Negro students in the Union. They
comprise an amorphous group of
between 40-50 students who gath-
er in the cafeteria every after
noon to eat, “shoot the breeze”
and play pinochle.
Who are they? How do they
mingle with white students? These
are glimpses of the experiences
they relate as they sip Cokes
and munch on pizza between
classes.
Social events is a major topic
these students discuss when
viewing their interaction with
whites.
“At dorm deserts, I don’t really
fit in,” said Gary, a cool College
Joe who talks fast and smiles a
lot. “They don’t play our kind of
music.”
“At one desert,” he continued
wryly, “I asked a white girl to
dance. She refused me, so I sat
down.”
Later, he noticed the girl danc-
ingdancing with white boys. He went over
to her and asked her for the next
record."
“Her girl friends were pushing
her to dance with me,” he re-
called. “So she did. We danced,
and in the middle of the record
she burst into tears and ran to
her housemother.”
Deducing a moral from his
story, Gary declared, “I don't
care if they don’t want to dance
with me, I just wish that before
each desert they’d make a list of
girls who won’t dance with me so
I'll know."
On the whole, Gary encounters
little "open" prejudice in his
dormitory. However, Donna, a
calm, attractive Negro student,
prefers to live at home and com-
mute rather than to room in a
dormitory.
At summer orientation last
July, she explained, she was the
only Negro in her tour group.
"They were surprised, I guess,
to see a Negro. They said
nothing against me, but they
stared as if they didn’t expect
Negroes note white preconceptions
to see a Negro in their group."
“I used to live in Philadelphia,"
Donna continued. "I was in the
minority... so I got used to the
feeling of being the only one there
and people staring."
But this feeling is "kind of
lonely," and that was why Donna
“declined living on campus--be
cause of summer orientation."
"I haven’t had any problems
with any students in class," she
continued. “They even come to
me and ask me for help. They
don’t judge you by your color, but
by what you can do." But Donna still prefers to live at home, rather than on campus.
Another commuter, Alphonso, was part of a nucleus of Negro students who tried to establish a “bi-racial" fraternity on cam- pus last spring. Plans were made to establish Omega Psi Phi, but due to a start late in the semes- ter, the group was unable to start a chapter.
Meeting ‘awkward’
“Many people who wanted to become charter members com- muted from Baltimore," Alphonso explained. It was “awkward for them to come back for a meeting at night." Also, a set sum of money had to be laid down within a one-week time limit. Gary feels that this payment deadline prevented the group from gen- erating more immediate interest.
Dwayne, a commuter who spends part of each afternoon in the Union improving his game of pinochle, explained why he would like to establish a fraternity.
“Everybody likes to have some- thing when they graduate, a group to call back together, a group to talk up old times. It’s good to be able to come back and look at the work you have done."
He and Alphonso also note that a fraternity would give the Negro students a chance to par- ticipate in Homecoming, to com- pete in athletic events, and to gain a voice in campus affairs.
Other Negroes disagree. They see little unity in a “bi-racial" fraternity, they anticipate that Negroes would remain together, and this would not alter signifi- cantly their present rate of in- teraction with whites.
Another student added that although Negroes have been “shunner" from “going into fra- ternities, “I would not join a fraternity simply (only) because it was black."
None of the 24 social frater nities on campus are racially integrated with whites and Ne- groes. The fraternities have no discriminatory clauses in their charters, but attitudinal barriers and apprehensive feel- ings seem to bar a Negro from pledging a white house.
These feelings are not fostered by white students alone. Negroes find they are reluctant to rush a white fraternity. They doubt that they would be pledged, and if they were, they wonder if they could be accepted as a brother.
Also, at parties, could the Ne- groes bring white dates without offending or shocking the alumni and brothers?
Interdating
These Negroes do interdate. They state that white girls are generally more friendly toward their race than white boys.
White people, they note, seem very concerned with pressures exerted by their friends. Negro boys dating white coeds have been told that when their dates return to the dormitory, every one in the hall flocks around them to ask questions.
If a Negro mixes socially with whites, however, peer-group re- action is minimal. Explained Gary, “If you’re in the group, you’re in... We don’t care... You do what you want to do."
White girls, they note, expect Negro boys to be fast on a date. They are surprised when they find Negro behavior to the con- trary. According to several Negro boys, colored girls are “a lot more shy than white girls."
“They don’t do things in pub lic," explained one boy. “On the Mall, I’ve seen things Negro girls won’t do."
Sorority obstacle
One thing Negro girls can’t do, it seems, is join a sorority. Last year, two Negro girls went through fall sorority rush. One girl received no invitations to the second round of parties, but the other girl was invited back to several houses. However, after this second group of par ties, that girl was dropped too.
This year another girl, Sharon, signed up for rush. Cute, petite and well-dressed, Sharon said she went through rush because she had taken it for granted that “you go to college, and you join a sorority."
“I was disappointed not to see some Negroes in the sororities," she said. “Out of 18 sororities, you would expect to see one. I was shocked. Especially on a campus this size. Rush was sup posed to be so open and all."
During rush, she reports, “everybody was nice." After open house she was invited back to ten houses. But for “set of four" parties, she received no return bids.
Negroes may join the service fraternity and sorority on cam- pus. Of the students interviewed, one was a member of Gamma Sig- ma Sigma sorority. Others were members of the marching band, P.E Majors Club, the football team, and the chess club.
A perusal through Terrapin yearbooks shows that other colored students are in Univer- sity Theater productions, publi- cations staffs, ROTC groups, the Nursing Club, the M Club and the Pharmacy Club.
But even in these groups, there are only one or two Negro mem- bers. The low proportion of Negro students on campus is not the lone factor preventing large Negro participation in campus activities.
The Negroes in the union "group" feel that a veil of ap- prehension limits Negro-white interaction outside of class. This cloak of apprehension is the last barrier for a Negro student to overcome before he will vie for acceptance in an all-white group. This cloak of apprehension is the last barrier that a white person must overcome before he will forget color, disregard nega- tive peer-group reactions and boldly sit down at a Negro table in the Union.
